Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Enabling Efficient Non-Linearities in Biomechanical Simulations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-linearities abound in any complex biomechanical simulation. As a human hand folds into a fist, non-linear contact and material forces give rise to characteristic bulges and folds. As red blood cells crowd down a capillary, advection and contact non-linearities cause them to bump and twirl. These essential dynamics are also the main computational challenges in a simulation.

This project investigates the efficient simulation of these and other biomechanical non-linearities. It specifically investigates projected physics methods, also known as model reduction methods, which have been known to accelerate simulations by multiple orders of magnitude, but also have trouble incorporating arbitrary non-linearities. The research team explores a variety of promising approaches, including multidimensional cubature, exponential integrators, and vector partitioning. Source code is routinely released into the public domain.

The project is driven by two main applications. The first is high-quality, virtual humans, which can be used in surgical simulation and training, as well as visual media. The second is simulating flexible micro-particles in blood flow, which assists in designing effective shapes that deliver radiation payloads to cancer sites. The visual results of this research are highly accessible to non-specialists, so they are packaged into a publicly available app that is used to engage undergraduate researchers, and used during high school outreach to encourage involvement in science and engineering.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated the development of fast biomechanical simulations. Two driving scenarios were proposed: virtual humans, and red blood cells immersed in a plasma flow. In particular, a class of fast simulation algorithms called “projected physics” methods was going to be used to accelerate these simulations by several orders of magnitude.

Both of these scenarios contain fundamental non-linearities, which is usually why this class of acceleration methods is not utilized. The PI and his team of researchers were able to overcome these limitations and design general new methods for handling non-linear physics within a projection framework. These new methods are described below.

1. A subspace “re-simulation” method for fluid dynamics was developed that allowed simulations to be performed over 9000 times faster than before. This was accomplished by devising a generalized form of “cubature” for fluid dynamics.

2. One of the most challenging non-linearities when simulating humans are self-contact non-linearities, e.g. when an elbow presses against a torso, or the head presses against the shoulder. This problem has been well-studied for decades, and successful new approaches usually accelerate existing algorithms by 10-20%. Using our new projected physics method, we were able to accelerate this phenomenon by an order of magnitude.

3. We generalized a classic acceleration method from mechanical engineering, known as “static condensation” to the more difficult non-linear regime. We called the new method “subspace condensation,” and hope that it will become a fundamental new tool for simulating solid mechanics.

4. One of the drawbacks of the projected physics approach that we leveraged in this project is that it can consume large amounts of memory. In order to address this, we devised a compression scheme that was able to reduce memory use by an order of magnitude, while only slowing down the underlying algorithm by a factor of three to four.

5. The problem of robustly coupling solids and fluids, i.e. red blood cells and surrounding plasma flow, introduced significant challenges to the projected physics framework. As a first step towards addressing these challenges, we developed a new, unified “Eulerian” method for simulating solids and fluids that are coupled in the same simulation. This new unified approach points the way forward to a fast projected physics algorithm that is able to handle all the non-linearities that arise in solids and fluids simultaneously.

Taken as a whole, the suite of methods that was developed during the course of this project represent the state-of-the-art in fast physics simulations. One unforeseen implication of this work is that it also represents a stepping-stone to even faster machine learning-based approaches to physical simulation in the future. While we developed methods to handle non-linearities, they were all within the context of a “linear basis”, i.e. all the results were linear combinations of existing physical configurations. The natural next step is to use a “non-linear basis”, which introduces both more representational power, but new computational challenges as well.

This grant supported 3 PhD students and two MS students. It has resulted in two PhD theses so far, with one final PhD thesis that will be completed using funds from a fellowship. It resulted in 9 publications, with one still under review. Six of these publications appeared in the journal of record for our field, ACM Transactions on Graphics, which reflects the fundamental nature of the work that took place. One of the other publications received a Best Paper Award, which also demonstrates the high quality of research that was accomplished.
